courses.subject: PHYS
courses.description: Introduction to the basic principles of physics and their applications to real-world phenomena.

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.description: Fundamental concepts in engineering mechanics, including statics and the application of Newton’s laws to engineering systems.

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.description: An introductory course that explores the basic principles of physics through practical applications and real-world examples.

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.description: Study of the physics of light and color, including the behavior of light, color perception, and applications of optics.

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.description: Exploration of sound and music through the principles of physics. Laboratory activities included.

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.description: An introductory seminar designed to expose students to current issues and research in the field of physics.

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.courseTitle: GENERAL PHYSICS FOR THE HEALTH SCIENCES
courses.description: Introduction to the principles of physics tailored for health science students, with applications to biological and medical sciences.

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.description: A course designed for future middle school science teachers focusing on physical science principles and classroom applications.

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.description: Introduction to classical mechanics and thermodynamics, non-calculus-based, for students in the life sciences.
prerequisites: MATH 115 or good standing in high school algebra and trigonometry

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.description: Continuation of PHYS 211, covering electricity, magnetism, and optics for non-science majors.

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.description: Advanced concepts in engineering mechanics, including dynamics and material properties, for engineering students.

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.description: Introduction to mechanics, energy, and momentum using calculus, designed for physics and engineering majors.

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.description: Continuation of PHYS 241, covering electromagnetism, optics, and modern physics concepts using calculus.
prerequisites: PHYS 241 (or a grade of B (3.0) or higher in PHYS 211)

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.description: Further study of electricity, magnetism, and waves, building on the principles covered in PHYS 242.

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.description: Advanced physics course covering classical mechanics, thermodynamics, and waves, designed for honors students.

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.description: Continuation of PHYS 251, covering electromagnetism, optics, and modern physics for honors students.

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.description: Individual project in any branch of physics. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.description: Introduction to hardware and software applications of computers in physics, including computer interfacing to experiments, computer aided design, LabView programming, data analysis, simulation and modeling techniques. Not open to students who have successfully completed PHYS 270.

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.description: Mathematical expressions for selected topics, such as forces and potentials, vector analysis, applications of Fourier series and complex variables, and solutions of the harmonic oscillator and wave equations.

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.description: A description of special relativity, quantum theory, atomic structure, and spectra.
prerequisites: or PHYS 212 with consent of instructor

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.description: Continuation of Modern Physics I, focusing on quantum mechanics, nuclear physics, and particle physics.

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.description: Application of physical principles and techniques to problems in biology, with emphasis on understanding cellular and subcellular structure and function.

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.description: Circuit components, characteristics of semi-conductors, electrical measurements, method of circuit analysis, electronic devices. Three lecture hours and one three-hour laboratory period.

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.description: Study of digital circuits, logic gates, and microcontrollers, with applications to physics experiments.

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.description: Experiments which defined modern physics. Exploration of classical and modern research methods: data acquisition and analysis, optical and nuclear spectroscopy. Six laboratory hours.

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.description: Several advanced experiments exploring methods currently used in research and industry. Familiarization with machine shop procedure, vacuum, low temperature and other experimental techniques. Six laboratory hours.

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.description: Systems of coordinates, kinematics, and transformations: Newtonian dynamics of particles and systems of particles; linear systems, oscillations, and series techniques; calculus of variations and the Lagrangian and Hamiltonian formulations; application of Lagrangians to gravitation/central force motion.

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.description: Principles and laws of classical thermodynamics applied to simple irreversible processes, including chemical, elastic, electric, and magnetic phenomena; thermodynamic functions and Maxwell's relations; the conservation equations in elementary kinetic theory; fluctuations; and irreversible transfer effects.
prerequisites: MATH 274 (may be taken concurrently with PHYS 243 or by permission)

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.description: Electrostatics, magnetostatics and electromagnetic radiation, including the Divergence Theorem and Stokes' Theorem, electrostatics in free space and dielectric materials, dielectric polarization, Laplace’s Equation, the Biot-Savart Law, the magnetic vector potential, inductance, magnetic materials, Maxwell's Equations in free space and in materials, and electrostatic boundary value problems.

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.description: Introduction to classical optics, including geometrical optics, wave optics, and optical instruments.

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.description: Students participate in colloquia on topics of current interest in physics research under guidance of instructor.

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.description: Supervised internship in a physics-related field. Students will apply their knowledge in real-world settings.

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.description: Individual project in any branch of physics. May be repeated for a maximum of 9 units.

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.description: Development of Einstein's general theory of relativity and its relevance to astrophysics: theory of gravity, relativistic effects of massive stars, black holes, gravity waves, cosmology.

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.description: Introduction to quantum mechanics, including the Schrödinger equation, wave functions, and quantum states. Applications to atoms and molecules are discussed.

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.description: Study of the properties of solids, including crystal structures, band theory, semiconductors, and magnetism.

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.description: It is impossible to imagine our modern technological society without magnetic materials. We use these materials and techniques virtually everywhere: in permanent magnets, sensors, information storage and processing. In this course, students will learn about the basic principles that govern different applications of magnetism and magnetic materials. We will discuss magnetic moments and their interactions, magnetic order and magnetic structures, implications of magnetism for real materials, experimental techniques and applications.

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.description: Experimental and theoretical methods for the study of nuclear and particle physics. Topics include properties of nuclei, nuclear transitions, nuclear models, nuclear reactions, relativistic interactions, symmetry, fundamental interactions, and contemporary models.

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.description: Introduction to the basic concepts and programming skills of computational physics. Students will develop their own computer programs to solve problems in mechanics, electromagnetism, quantum mechanics, chaos, nonlinear dynamics, and other areas. No previous computer programming experience is required.

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.description: Special topics in the area of physics. Special topics will be determined by current interests of the faculty and the needs of the curriculum.

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.description: Seminar series for advanced physics students to present and discuss their research and current topics in physics.

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.description: Individual study in an area of physics chosen in consultation with a faculty member. Requires final research or written report.

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.description: Independent reading in physics, focused on specific topics of interest in the field. Final paper required.

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.description: Research problems in a specific area of physics. Students will develop and complete a project under the supervision of a faculty member.

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.description: Individual projects in any branch of physics. At the completion of a project, students must write a formal research paper on the work done.
prerequisites: Consent of the faculty member who will mentor the research project

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.description: Writing of an honors thesis based on independent research done under the direction of a faculty member.
prerequisites: Consent of the faculty member who will mentor the research project
